abstracts.cdata!:
The overall assessment of the
            project's achievement of its major objectives is
            satisfactory. World Bank performance was satisfactory, while
            the Borrower's performance was mixed. Lessons learned
            included the following: The project should have been
            implemented over a longer period consistent with the longer
            term objectives, especially in face of the need for
            continuing monitoring and evaluation, and for developing
            operational capacity and the regulatory framework. Projects
            supporting environmental management should follow a program
            approach such as the current Adaptable Program Lending
            (APL), which provides flexibility in meeting evolving needs.
            Efforts to integrate multiple executing agencies must be
            supported by work across sectors to improve coordination,
            and implementation must be preceded by awareness-raising.
            Alternative fee arrangements under the follow-up project
            could fill some of the gap in funding and enhance
            sustainability of the operations. A full and thorough review
            of government actions and financing is important when
            assessing commitment and ownership of projects. Mechanisms
            should have been developed which involved the private sector
            and civil society in monitoring environmental compliance.
            The same strategy cannot be used to obtain and sustain
            community participation; selection criteria for pilots
            should emphasize the willingness of communities to fully
            participate in implementation action plans, and should
            identify socio-cultural differences.
